item.title: Palabra del día en inglés: ‘arid’
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 113 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Word of the Day: arid
item.description: This word has appeared in 113 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: How the Quarter-Zip Sweater Became a Symbol of Maturity for Gen Z
item.description: How one of the stodgiest garments in the Western wardrobe caught on with the Nike Tech crowd.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia

item.title: La primera ministra de Japón comunica a través de su bolso
item.description: La directora de moda de Vogue Japón dijo que el bolso de Takaichi sirve para subrayar su imagen de mujer profesional y refuerza su promesa electoral de “trabajar y trabajar y trabajar y trabajar”.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman

media:content.media:description: La primera ministra de Japón, Sanae Takaichi, con su característico bolso Hamano, que se agotó tras su elección.

item.title: I’m in Venezuela. This Is the True Cost of Trump’s Gunboat Diplomacy.
item.description: Trump’s show of force toward Venezuela has created a disastrous political trap — for Venezuelans most of all.
item.dc:creator: Phil Gunson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: A Venezuelan soldier in Caracas, Venezuela, earlier this month.

item.title: El príncipe de Arabia Saudita tiene grandes planes, pero su enorme fondo carece de liquidez
item.description: Tras casi una década de inversiones caras y fallidas, Mohammed bin Salman supervisa una reestructuración del importante fondo de riqueza del reino.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland and Vivian Nereim

media:content.media:description: El presidente Trump recibió el martes en la Casa Blanca al príncipe heredero Mohammed bin Salman de Arabia Saudita.

item.title: Lobos ladrones: un video capta hasta dónde llegan por conseguir comida
item.description: Una loba fue captada arrastrando una trampa para cangrejos fuera del agua para obtener un tentempié. Algunos científicos aseguran que ese comportamiento demuestra su capacidad para usar herramientas.
item.dc:creator: Lesley Evans Ogden

item.title: Mexico Wins Miss Universe Pageant Marred by Scandal
item.description: Fátima Bosch was crowned in Thailand on Friday. The competition got off to a rocky start this month when she briefly walked out after being scolded by an organizer.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado

media:content.media:description: Mexico's Fátima Bosch was named Miss Universe on Friday.

item.title: Representative Eric Swalwell Will Run for California Governor
item.description: Representative Eric Swalwell, a Democrat, is likely to emphasize his history of fighting President Trump, an approach that many Democratic voters say they want their elected officials to take.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall

media:content.media:description: Representative Eric Swalwell is the latest Democrat to announce he will run for California governor.

item.title: Survivors Describe Deadly Snowstorm in Chilean Patagonia
item.description: Five tourists, from Mexico, Britain and Germany, died Monday on a popular hiking trail in the Torres del Paine National Park.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka and Pascale Bonnefoy

media:content.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Carabineros de Chile
media:content.media:description: A picture released by Chile’s Carabineros shows a rescue team at the end of their search and recovery operation for a group of tourists.

item.title: Reseña de ‘Wicked: Por Siempre’: mejores amigas hasta el final
item.description: Cynthia Erivo y Ariana Grande regresan a Oz en la segunda parte de la adaptación cinematográfica del musical de Broadway.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: After Syria’s 14-Year Civil War, a Search for Victims Leads to Mass Graves
item.description: More than 100,000 people disappeared during the 13-year civil war. To bring closure to some of their families, the new government faces the challenging task of exhuming remains from scores of burial sites.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A trench at the Najha cemetery near Damascus, Syria. The area is believed to hold a mass grave.

item.title: Researcher’s Smuggling Arrest Casts Light on Dispute Over Chinese Students
item.description: As some lawmakers press U.S. universities to curtail ties with China, a postdoctoral student’s prosecution raises questions about how big the danger actually is.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni

item.title: Four Months Into Dating, She Moved Across the Country with Him
item.description: When Seun Akinboboye asked his new girlfriend, Taylar Wade, to relocate to San Francisco, she didn’t want to wonder “what if.”
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova

item.title: An Army Captain Asked His Server About Herself. She Wasn’t Interested (Yet).
item.description: Neither Shaylah Nichols nor Jordan Lee was looking for anything serious in Honolulu. A late-night talk and lots of laughs changed that.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora

item.title: A Painful Family Discovery, and the Love Story That Followed
item.description: After a revelation about her ancestors, Elizabeth Thomas moved to Washington, D.C., found a fulfilling career and met Anthony Gregg.
item.dc:creator: Ama Sarpomaa

item.title: I Was Deemed Unfit to Be a Mother
item.description: After losing custody of my son, I fought to prove my love to him. That was a mistake.
item.dc:creator: Kate Gilgan

item.title: She Adopted on Her Own. Then Love Found Both of Them.
item.description: Amy Krasner assumed her love life was over when she became a single mother with a busy career. Then along came Douglas Robb.
item.dc:creator: Leslie Katz

item.title: Corrections: Nov. 21, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 21, 2025.

item.title: Quote of the Day: The Hunt Is On for Bears in Japan After Deadly Attacks
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 21, 2025.

item.title: Justice Dept. Sues California Over College Benefits for Undocumented Students
item.description: The lawsuit is the third filed by the Justice Department against the state in a week.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman

media:content.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The University of California, Los Angeles, campus.

item.title: Trump and Mamdani to Meet at the White House
item.description: President Trump and Zohran Mamdani, the mayor-elect of New York City, were expected to meet on Friday at the White House. The meeting comes after months of trading insults.
item.dc:creator: Jiawei Wang

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani said he hoped to discuss affordability, public safety and economic security for New Yorkers when he meets President Trump on Friday.

item.title: Australia Adds Twitch to Social Media Ban for Teens
item.description: Twitch, a livestreaming service popular with gamers, joins nine other platforms that will be required to remove Australian users under the age of 16.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado

media:content.media:description: The ban will take effect on Dec. 10, about a year after Parliament passed one of the world’s most comprehensive measures to protect children and teenagers from potential harm on the internet.

item.title: NJ Transit Cancels Service to and From Midtown Until Friday Morning
item.description: Passengers on the Midtown Direct lines were being dropped off at the Hoboken station because of a repair to a rail switch nearby.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez

media:content.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: NJ Transit announced the suspension of service on Thursday night, after a day of delays disrupted commutes for tens of thousands of riders.

item.title: Un retrato de Frida Kahlo se vende por 55 millones de dólares, un récord para un artista latinoamericano
item.description: El autorretrato surrealista fue realizado en 1940, un año turbulento en la vida de la artista mexicana en el que su salud y su matrimonio se deterioraron.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Tim F. Schneider

item.title: ‘Two Strangers’ Review: Meeting Cute, Toting Baggage
item.description: The effervescent musical, a new London import, delivers lavishly on the promise of a rom-com: laughter, escape and fantasy.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes and Sara Krulwich
item.category: Two Strangers (Carry a Cake Across New York) (Play)

media:content.media:description: Sammy Tutty, left, plays the irrepressible Dougal opposite Christiani Pitts as the no-nonsense Robin in “Two Strangers Carry a Cake Across New York” at the Longacre Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Nov. 21, 2025
item.description: Joyce Keller makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

media:content.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Get ready to fall for Joyce Keller’s debut puzzle.

item.title: Anxiety Over A.I. Spending Returns to Global Markets
item.description: A sharp reversal in Asian stocks, after a rally fueled by Nvidia’s strong earnings, underscores how fears of an A.I. bubble are driving broad market swings.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis

media:content.media:description: The Kospi index in South Korea fell more than 3 percent in early trading in Asia on Friday.

item.title: Pras Michel of the Fugees Gets 14 Years for Illegal Foreign Influence Scheme
item.description: Mr. Michel was convicted in April 2023 of 10 criminal counts, including money laundering, illegal lobbying and witness tampering.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler

media:content.media:description: Pras Michel outside the federal courthouse in Washington during his trial in 2023.

item.title: Duchess Potatoes
item.description: Prized for its presentation, this fancy French potato dish, Duchess potatoes, dates back to the 1700s, when it was created — and given its aristocratic name — to help elevate the reputation of the humble tuber in France, where it had yet to be widely embraced by home cooks.
item.dc:creator: Nyt Cooking

item.title: Trump’s National Guard Blunder
item.description: A brief history of the National Guard in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Marina King, Jan Kobal and Amanda Su
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Can the Right Confront Antisemitism in Its Ranks?
item.description: Why is it so hard for the right to draw a boundary at antisemitism in its coalition? According to Yoram Hazony, an Israeli political theorist, it’s because the group wasn’t prepared to navigate the “explosion” of antisemitism. In this week’s “Interesting Times,” he tells Ross Douthat how future leaders can have a bigger tent without giving people like Nick Fuentes “a seat at the table.”
item.dc:creator: Interesting Times

item.title: CIA Kryptos Auction: Anonymous Bidder Pays Nearly $1 Million for Secret to Decode Sculpture
item.description: The creator of the Kryptos panels, Jim Sanborn, sought to unburden himself of the puzzle, and then discovered before an auction he had archived its solution in the Smithsonian.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz

media:content.media:description: Jim Sanborn, the artist who created the Kryptos sculpture, at the International Spy Museum in Washington earlier this month.

item.title: Is the Gaza War Contributing to Antisemitism?
item.description: Is the recent onslaught of antisemitism on the right a result of the Israel-Hamas war? In this episode of “Interesting Times,” Yoram Hazony, an Israeli political theorist, explains how foreign policy is just one of the various forms that anti-Jewish messaging can take.
item.dc:creator: Interesting Times

item.title: Qaeda Convict Returns to Guantánamo Court 17 Years After Trial
item.description: The Yemeni prisoner spent nearly seven hours at the war court, displaying some of the defiance of his 2008 proceeding.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: An abandoned prison camp at Guantánamo Bay. Ali Hamza al-Bahlul, who was sentenced to life in 2008, appeared at the base war court on Thursday in a proceeding concerning the upcoming capital trial of another prisoner.

item.title: Six Stunning Thanksgiving Pies
item.description: We put Sue Li in charge of the pies this year, and she delivered six stunners.
item.dc:creator: Vaughn Vreeland

media:content.media:credit: Johnny Miller for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Sue Li. Prop Stylist: Sarah Smart.
media:content.media:description: Pies!

item.title: Trump and Mamdani Are Meeting for the First Time. Will They Play Nice?
item.description: Zohran Mamdani, the mayor-elect of New York City, will go to the White House on Friday. The stakes are high for the city.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani said he hoped to discuss affordability, public safety and economic security for New Yorkers when he meets President Trump on Friday.

item.title: Frida Kahlo Portrait Sells for $55 Million, Setting Her Auction Record
item.description: The surrealistic self-portrait was made in 1940, a turbulent year in the Mexican artist’s life as her health and marriage deteriorated.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Tim F. Schneider

media:content.media:description: Bidding for Frida Kahlo, “El sueño (La cama),” or “The dream (The bed),” at Sotheby’s auction house in Manhattan. It sold for $55 million at auction Thursday night, breaking the artist’s record.

item.title: Hundreds of Invasive Goldfish to Be Culled From Ottawa Pond
item.description: Thousands washed ashore dead in the spring, but the fish are back. “They’re pretty hard to kill,” a biology professor said.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

item.title: Storm Moves Through Texas, Bringing Nine Inches of Rain or More
item.description: Hundreds of flights were canceled in Dallas on Thursday, and officials warned of flooding across much of the state.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff

item.title: Judge Concludes Prosecutors Can Circumvent Federal Grand Juries in D.C.
item.description: The ruling by a federal judge found that federal prosecutors could fall back on local grand juries to approve serious charges when they failed to persuade a federal grand jury.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague

media:content.media:description: The decision by Chief Judge James E. Boasberg of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia applied immediately only to Kevontae Stewart, a Washington resident.

item.title: Coast Guard Says Swastika and Noose Displays Are No Longer Hate Incidents
item.description: A new servicewide policy recasts swastikas and nooses as “politically divisive,” revises harassment provisions and deletes protections for transgender troops.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay and Minho Kim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A member of the Coast Guard patrolling the waterways near President Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida.

item.title: Missouri Judge Who Wore Elvis Wig in Court Agrees to Resign
item.description: Judge Matthew E.P. Thornhill also talked about politics and played Elvis songs in court, a judicial commission said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Michael Levenson

media:content.media:description: “Elvis was a super talent,” Matthew E.P. Thornhill, a circuit judge in St. Charles County, Mo., said last year in a local television interview. “If I just had Elvis’s hair, I’d be unstoppable.”

item.title: U.S. Ambassador to Canada Channels Harsh Trump Tone
item.description: Pete Hoekstra’s bluntness is seen as undiplomatic by Canadian officials and interpreted as a way for the Trump administration to turn up the heat as trade talks drag on.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff

media:content.media:credit: Jeff Mcintosh/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Pete Hoekstra, the American ambassador to Canada, speaking in Banff, Alberta, in September.

item.title: Netflix, Comcast and Paramount Submit Warner Bros. Discovery Bids
item.description: The outcome of the sale could alter the trajectory of the entertainment business.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin, Lauren Hirsch and Nicole Sperling

media:content.media:description: The studio in Burbank, Calif., could be included in a deal for Warner Bros. Discovery that Netflix, Paramount and Comcast are seeking.

item.title: ‘The Age of Disclosure,’ Documentary About U.F.O.s, Gets a Congressional Audience
item.description: “The Age of Disclosure,” a documentary featuring government and military officials, was screened for a bipartisan group of members of the House of Representatives.
item.dc:creator: Ralph Blumenthal and Leslie Kean

media:content.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The director Dan Farah at a showing of his film, “The Age of Disclosure,” in Washington.

item.title: Ward Landrigan, Jeweler to the Stars, Dies at 84
item.description: At Sotheby’s, he provided famous diamonds to Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton before reviving Verdura, a venerable jewelry company founded by a Sicilian duke.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

media:content.media:description: Through his jewelry house Verdura, Ward Landrigan catered to high-society figures as well as celebrities like Brooke Shields, Sofia Coppola and the fashion designer Carolina Herrera.

item.title: No, presidente, no podemos ‘dejarlo así’
item.description: La forma de actuar del presidente Trump cuando recibió al príncipe heredero Mohammed bin Salman en el Despacho Oval fue aduladora y vergonzosa.
item.dc:creator: El Comité Editorial
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Energy Department Reorganization Reflects Shift Away From Renewable Energy
item.description: The reorganization reflects the ongoing shift in the federal government’s energy priorities: less renewable energy, more fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer

media:content.media:description: The Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy and the Office of Clean Energy Demonstrations no longer appear in an organizational chart posted by the Energy Department on Tuesday.

item.title: Hiring Increased, but So Did the Unemployment Rate
item.description: Also, bear attacks are disrupting life in rural Japan. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
